claim: Restricting to exams dated after 1997-01-01, the count of inactivated partial prothrombin time results is 51.
extra_info: examinations done after 1997/1/1 refers to `Examination Date` > '1997-01-01'; normal activated partial prothrom bin time refesr to APTT < 45;
reasoning: The claim states that restricting to exams dated after 1997-01-01, the count of inactivated partial prothrombin time results is 51. The Laboratory table has an APTT column and a Date column. Per the hint, normal APTT < 45, so 'inactivated' (abnormal) APTT means APTT >= 45. Querying COUNT(*) FROM Laboratory WHERE Date > '1997-01-01' AND APTT >= 45 returns exactly 51, matching the claim.

content.text: I'll start by exploring the database schema to understand the structure and then verify the claim.

input.description: List all tables in the database

content.content:
CREATE TABLE Examination
(
    ID                 INTEGER          null,
    `Examination Date` DATE         null,
    `aCL IgG`          REAL        null,
    `aCL IgM`          REAL        null,
    ANA                INTEGER          null,
    `ANA Pattern`      TEXT null,
    `aCL IgA`          INTEGER          null,
    Diagnosis          TEXT null,
    KCT                TEXT null,
    RVVT              TEXT null,
    LAC                TEXT null,
    Symptoms           TEXT null,
    Thrombosis         INTEGER          null,
    foreign key (ID) references Patient (ID)
            on update cascade on delete cascade
);
CREATE TABLE Patient
(
    ID           INTEGER default 0 not null
        primary key,
    SEX          TEXT  null,
    Birthday     DATE          null,
    Description  DATE          null,
    `First Date` DATE          null,
    Admission    TEXT  null,
    Diagnosis    TEXT  null
);
CREATE TABLE Laboratory
(
    ID        INTEGER  default 0            not null,
    Date      DATE default '0000-00-00' not null,
    GOT       INTEGER                       null,
    GPT       INTEGER                        null,
    LDH       INTEGER                        null,
    ALP       INTEGER                        null,
    TP        REAL             null,
    ALB       REAL             null,
    UA        REAL             null,
    UN        INTEGER                       null,
    CRE       REAL             null,
    `T-BIL`   REAL             null,
    `T-CHO`   INTEGER                       null,
    TG        INTEGER                       null,
    CPK       INTEGER                       null,
    GLU       INTEGER                       null,
    WBC       REAL             null,
    RBC       REAL             null,
    HGB       REAL             null,
    HCT       REAL             null,
    PLT       INTEGER                       null,
    PT        REAL             null,
    APTT      INTEGER                       null,
    FG        REAL             null,
    PIC       INTEGER                       null,
    TAT       INTEGER                       null,
    TAT2      INTEGER                       null,
    `U-PRO`   TEXT              null,
    IGG       INTEGER                       null,
    IGA       INTEGER                       null,
    IGM       INTEGER                       null,
    CRP       TEXT              null,
    RA        TEXT              null,
    RF        TEXT              null,
    C3        INTEGER                       null,
    C4        INTEGER                       null,
    RNP       TEXT              null,
    SM        TEXT              null,
    SC170     TEXT              null,
    SSA       TEXT              null,
    SSB       TEXT              null,
    CENTROMEA TEXT              null,
    DNA       TEXT              null,
    `DNA-II`  INTEGER                       null,
    primary key (ID, Date),
        foreign key (ID) references Patient (ID)
            on update cascade on delete cascade
);

content.text:
Now I can see the schema. The claim mentions "inactivated partial prothrombin time results" - looking at the schema, the relevant column is `APTT` (activated partial thromboplastin time) in the `Examination` table... actually, it's in the `Laboratory` table. The claim says "inactivated" which likely means results that are NOT activated/normal. Based on the hint, normal APTT < 45, so "inactivated" likely means APTT >= 45 (abnormal). Wait, let me re-read the claim - it says "inactivated partial prothrombin time." This seems to refer to APTT values that indicate inactivation, but the hint says "normal activated partial prothrombin time refers to APTT < 45."

The claim is about exams dated after 1997-01-01, but APTT is in the Laboratory table, not the Examination table. Let me check the Laboratory table which has a `Date` column.

input.command: sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/thrombosis_prediction.sqlite" "SELECT COUNT(*) FROM Laboratory WHERE Date > '1997-01-01' AND APTT >= 45;"
input.description: Count inactivated APTT results (>=45) after 1997-01-01 in Laboratory

input.command: sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/thrombosis_prediction.sqlite" "SELECT COUNT(*) FROM Examination WHERE \"Examination Date\" > '1997-01-01';"

content.text:
The query on the Laboratory table for APTT >= 45 (inactivated/abnormal partial thromboplastin time) with dates after 1997-01-01 returns exactly **51**, which matches the claim.

Let me also verify the interpretation: "inactivated" likely means abnormal APTT, i.e., APTT >= 45 (since normal is APTT < 45 per the hint).

The Laboratory table has an APTT column and a Date column. Per the hint, normal APTT < 45, so 'inactivated' (abnormal) APTT means APTT >= 45. Querying COUNT(*) FROM Laboratory WHERE Date > '1997-01-01' AND APTT >= 45 returns exactly 51, matching the claim."}
